Award.AbstractNarration:
How repeated experiences affect human memory is a fundamental question in cognitive science that is applicable to issues in education, training, and law. Because events and contexts tend to change over time, repeated experiences are rarely identical to prior experiences, but instead contain elements of earlier experiences. Science has established that a prior experience with something will generally affect memory for a later variant of its occurrence. Sometimes this effect is beneficial and sometimes it is detrimental to later memory. Whereas some events that contain repeated elements of prior experiences are remembered better than events that are completely new, others are actually remembered more poorly than events that are new. This project aims to better understand why some previous experiences facilitate memory for later variants of those experiences and others instead seem to interfere with it. The research has relevance to the development of effective learning programs and training systems, as well as to educational practice.

One factor shown to impact whether a later variant of an earlier experience will be remembered better or worse than a new experience is whether the repeated elements remind the person of the earlier experience or not. If reminding occurs, the repeated event is remembered better than a new event; if reminding fails, the repeated event is actually remembered worse than a new event. Much of what science has established thus far about how repeated experiences affect memory is based on test performance, which involves controlled attempts to remember in response to prompts. Yet in everyday life, reminding is often brought on spontaneously by cues in ongoing experience, without a test explicitly prompting the person to remember. This project will employ experimental manipulations of the relations between earlier and later events to determine what elicits spontaneous reminding, how spontaneous reminding differs from deliberate attempts to remember, and how these two types of reminding affect later memory. This research will increase understanding of the operation of human memory processes across ongoing experience, and the impact that these processes have on later memory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Much of what science knows about people?s memory and learning is based on performance on tests, that is, on people?s deliberate attempts to remember. Yet in everyday life, remembering is often triggered spontaneously by cues in ongoing experience, without a teacher or tester prompting us to remember.  Such spontaneous remembering seems to play a critical role in allowing people to benefit from the repetition of events during learning, and spontaneous remembering also plays a critical role in managing the potential detrimental memory effects of experiencing events that change from time to time. The project investigated how to measure spontaneous memories during ongoing learning, and investigated the role that spontaneous remembering plays in learning and forgetting of repeated events and changed events. Finally, it investigated who is more prone to notice that events are changing over time, and what environmental conditions affect the likelihood of noticing changes over time.

The first goal was to test whether teaching people to say aloud whatever they are thinking, so-called verbal protocols, could detect spontaneous remindings of earlier learning during later learning. Talk aloud protocols demonstrated truly spontaneous remembering. We also measured reminding by asking people to report whether current events reminded them of a prior event during new learning, as a goal secondary to the goal of new learning, and found that measurement technique was useful for tracking remindings with little effect on the likelihood of remindings.

We tested whether noticing that events are repeating over time is necessary for learning. In a striking and counterintuitive finding, when people did not notice that material they were learning had been well-learned in an earlier situation, their learning of the repeated material showed no significant benefit from the prior learning. We also investigated how being reminded of an earlier, similar event facilitates memory for both events. In contrast, when reminding fails to occur, there is competition in memory to the detriment of memory for both events. We traced the effects of reminding on memory competition over long delays, and showed that the retrieval of the earlier event in the act of being reminded slows forgetting of that earlier event.

The project investigated the conditions for noticing relationships between events across time.  Reminding is more likely when events unfold slowly, and when the environmental context and people?s task is the same between earlier and later events, and when the material being learned is distinctive. We also found preliminary evidence of individual differences in reminding across events that are associated with cognitive reflectiveness.

We extended our experiments to situations where people learn facts that turn out to be erroneous, and then later need to update those facts. Being reminded of the erroneous fact during updating enhanced learning of the updated fact. Understanding the processes of reminding holds promise for improving the efficiency and effectiveness of educational practice and training.
